My little contribution in Indian Odonatology

The checklist of Odonata fauna of the Asansol – Durgapur Industrial region received six more species officially after this publication. It took a four-year-long period of time, I apologize for that. The addition of six more species of dragonflies & damselflies has been reported by me in a paper published in the current issue (published on 26 February 2020) of the Journal of Threatened Taxa (www.threatenedtaxa.org). It is my pleasure to share the work with you. Please follow this link (https://doi.org/10.11609/jott.5138.12.3.15391-15394) or go to the site for accessing it. In this regard, I would like to thank all members of the Dragonfly South Asia group, my filed supporters and well-wishers due to whom I have successfully done this job. And for the previous report hit this link
https://doi.org/10.11609/jott.2572.8.2.8503-8517

Dear all, 

Purab Chowdhury found more than seventy five Tiny Hooded Dartlets

i.e. Indian Hooded Dartlets (Agriocnemis kalinga) on last Sunday 29.12.19

at Rajarhat birding area, very adjacent to Kolkata in North 24-Parganas,

southern West Bengal, eastern India !

More than seventy five Tiny Hooded Dartlets at a time at a place !

Unbelievable ! Simply unbelievable !

We were also there at that site on that day !

It is a newly discovered species and described by Manoj V. Nair &

K. A. Subramanian in 2015 and it's the smallest odonate (13 mm),

mainly available in eastern India and has many variations.

**Congrats** Purab !

Cheers ! S.Patra, SundayWatch, 31.12.19, 1.53 p.m.

I was out with my camera, photographing a pair of Golden Dartlet damselflies(Ischnura rubilio), one of the prettiest damselflies of our region. They were ready to mate and he was holding the female. The males uses his anal-appendages to clasp the female by the neck . Once the male tightens his grip its difficult for a female to escape .

While I was busy clicking few images, suddently a female Ground skimmer(Diplacodes trivialis ) came and caught the mating pair and started feeding on the male Golden Dartlet while the female damselfly was still hanging on to the male. I could see the tiny female damselfly was frantically flapping her wings and shaking her body to get away from her mate . In a few minutes it was over. The Ground skimmer finished her meal of that golden Dartlet male, along with the helpless female. And thats how life goes on in the amazing world of Insects !

So we asked why damselflies have these beautiful blue bands on their abdomen. We tested if females like these blue bands but found that female did not choose their mate based on male colour (why will you? colour changes! and not always tells how good the males are). We, however, found that males blue bands tell other males not to mate with them (aka, I am not the date you are looking mate; please don't waste your and my time please). 

Moral: When life is short, competition for mating is very high, and everyone around you is crazy for coupling, it is vital to express your sexual preference, nicely but boldly.
